questions: Q. 2. Where are the pigment located in photosynthetic bacteria ?
answers: Ans. The pigments in photosynthetic bacteria are located in the folds of cell membrane.

questions: Q. 3. What will happen if a plant is given only green light ?
answers: Ans. If a plant is given only green light, no photosynthesis will occur. Green light is not absorbed by the photosynthetic pigments as it is reflected back as such.

questions: Q. 4. Name the central element present in chlorophyll.
answers: Ans. Magnesium is the central element in chlorophyll.

answers: Ans. RuBisCO

questions: Q. 14. How many molecules of ATP and how many molecules of NADPH + ğ‡+ are spent to fix three molecules of CğğŸ ?
answers: Ans. Fixation of three molecules of CO2 uses 9 ATP and 6 NADPH molecules in C3 plants.In C4 plants for fixation of 3 CO2 molecules 15 ATP and 6 NADPH and 6 NADPH energy is equired.

questions: Q. 15. What is the site of formation of glycoxylate from glycolate?
answers: Ans. The site of formation of glyoxylate from glycolate is peroxisomes of mesophyll cells.

questions: Q. 16. Why are the ğ‚ğŸ’ plants more efficient in picking up CğğŸ when it is found in low concentration.
answers: Ans. The C4 plants are more efficient in picking up CO4 even when it is found in low concentration because of the high affinity of PEP.

questions: Q. 18. What is assimilatory power ?
answers: Ans. Chemical energy of ATP and reducing power of NADP H2 , are assimilatory powers.

questions: Q. 19. In what form carbohydrates are translocated in plants ?
answers: Ans. Carbohydrates are translocated in plants in the form of sucrose.

questions: Q. 20. What is photon ? What is the term given to the energy contained in photon ?
answers: Ans. Discrete partidles believed to be present in light are called photons. The energy contained in a photon is termed as quantum.

questions: Q. 21. Why are the C, plants more affected by high temperatures ?
answers: Ans. At high temperature ğ‚ğŸ‘ plants are more affected because of increased affinity of RuBisCo to oxygen.

questions: Q. 22. Name three cell organelles involved photorespiration.
answers: Ans. Chloroplast, Mitochondria and Peroxisomes.

questions: Q. 23. Name the CğğŸ acceptor in ğ‚ğŸ’ cycle.
answers: Ans. It is a distinct morphological structural unit in the thylakoid which embodies a photosynthetic unit.

questions: Q. 25. A potted plant otherwise kept in sunlight,ih shifted to monochromatic red light Will the rate of photosynthesis increase, decrease or remain the same ?
answers: Ans. Decrease.

questions: Q. 26. Where is NADP reductase enzyme located ?
answers: Ans. NADP reductase enzyme is located on the stroma side of the membrane.

questions: Q. 27. How does the light beyond the saturation point affect photosynthesis?
answers: Ans. Beyond the saturation point, an increase in incident light causes the breakdown of chlorophyll and a decreased process of photosynthesis.

questions: Q. 28. What is Kranz anatomy ?
answers: Ans. Kranz anatomy is the special structure of leaves in C4 PLANTS (eg. maize) where the tissue equivalent to the spongy mesophyll cells is clustered in a ring around the leaf veins, outside the bundle-sheath cells.

questions: Q. 29. Which compound acts as C ğğŸ acceptor in Calvin cycle ?
answers: Ans. Ribulose-1-5-biphosphate, a 5-carbon compound is the acceptor of C O2 in Calvin cycle.

questions: Q. 30. Name the primary acceptor of carbon dioxide in ğ‚ğŸ‘ and ğ‚ğŸ’ plants.
answers: Ans. C3 plants : 5 Carbon Ketose Sugar, Ribulose-1,5- bisphosphate (RuBP) C4 plants: 3Carbon molecule phosphoend pyruvate (PEP).

questions: Q. 31. Name the hormones which increase and decrease the rate of photosynthesis.
answers: Ans. Cytokinins and gibberellins increase and ABA decrease the rate of photosynthesis.

questions: Q. 32. Why are transitional curves produced during low of limiting factor?
answers: Ans. The transitional curves are produced because of the presence of a large number of green cells and numerous chloroplast in the cell.

questions: Q. 33. Define light compensation point ?
answers: Ans. The point in light intensity where no gaseous exchange occur during photosynthesis is called as light compensation point.

questions: Q. 34. What is CğğŸ compensation point ?
answers: Ans. When CO2 conc. is reduced, there comes a point at which illuminated plant stop absorbing CO2 from the environment, it is known as C O2 compensation point.

questions: Q. 35. Name the first CğğŸ fixation produced in ğ‚ğŸ’ plants.
answers: Ans. Oxaloacetic acid (OAA)

questions: Q. 36. What is Warburg effect?
answers: Ans. At very high oxygen content, the rate of photosynthesis begins to decline in all plants, this phenomenon is called Warburg effect.

questions: Q. 37. What is red drop ?
answers: Ans. Red drop is the occasional fall in photosynthetic yield beyond red region of spectrum (Emersor 1943). This is also called Emerson effect.

questions: Q. 38. What are antennae in photosystem ?
answers: Ans. Antennae refers to all the pigments of the photosystem except the pigment molecule (Chlâ€™aâ€™) that forms the reaction centre.

questions: Q. 39. Where does calvin cycle takes place in (i) a ğ‚ğŸ‘ plant and (i) a ğ‚ğŸ’ plant respectively.
answers: Ans. (i) In a C3 plant, it takes place in the mesophyll cells. (ii) In a C4plant, calvin cycle takes place in the bundle sheath cells.
